content: So I'm trying to find better ways to capture lang team activity
One thing I was trying is creating issues on the lang-team repository for active project groups
https://github.com/rust-lang/lang-team/labels/project-group
I also have been updating this github project:
https://github.com/rust-lang/lang-team/projects/2
the idea was that we were supposed to "assign" the issue for each project group to its leads + liaison
but I can't actually do that in all cases for some reason or another, probably because the relevant folks aren't members of the rust org? not sure
I was also hoping that we could post "status updates" to the issues instead of in the paper doc
If they comment on the issue, you can assign them
(it's incredibly awkward)
I think it's probably a bug that they are not members of the org
i.e., the project groups are represented in the team repo
but maybe they don't have a github team associated with them
would that change anything?
yeah if they're members of the org should be assignable I think, likely we'd want to add teams anyway for project groups (because of cc @rust-lang/inline-asm for example)
right example
I do feel a bit of tension I have to say around organizing this "by team"
I think i's the right way to go for now
but I feel like it'd be nice if we had a more centralized setup and a rust-lang/meta or something with T-lang labels etc
since I suspect many projects will cross-cut (e.g., const-eval)
but .. I don't know, that has its problems too
hm well one thing I'll note
that the github projects thingy can be cross-repo (org wide that is)
and it does seem like having a single "primary" team is good
one problem i've noted with the async-await stuff
is that there are just very different 'mindsets'
e.g., there is a need for polish, and a need to design traits, and lang features
it's not obviously great to mash them e.g. into one zulip stream
and clearly not one meeting
I do think there's nothing wrong with a single project group having multiple streams/issue trackers/etc
otoh, there is a lot of overlap between the people
(when it's silo'd into multiple homes, so to speak)
I have to say that organizing things via a github repo feels a lot better than the paper doc
